content.title: Smoking Cessation
content.summary: Smoking cessation is the most important intervention for preventing tobacco-related disease. A combination of pharmacotherapy (varenicline, NRT, bupropion) and behavioral counseling provides the highest quit rates. All clinicians should use the 5 A's framework (Ask, Advise, Assess, Assist, Arrange) at every patient encounter.
key_points: Smoking is leading preventable cause of death: COPD, lung cancer, cardiovascular disease
Varenicline is most effective single agent; combination NRT comparable
Combination pharmacotherapy + counseling provides highest quit rates (30-40%)
5 A's: Ask (tobacco use), Advise (quit), Assess (readiness), Assist (intervention), Arrange (follow-up)
Brief advice (<3 min) increases quit rates by 30% compared to no advice
Relapse is common - treat as chronic relapsing condition, not single event
content.statement: Smoking cessation requires combining pharmacotherapy (varenicline preferred) with behavioral counseling, utilizing the 5 A's framework at every clinical encounter, while treating nicotine dependence as a chronic relapsing condition.

explanation.intuition: Think of nicotine addiction as a two-headed monster: physical dependence (nicotine receptors) and behavioral habit (triggers, rituals). Pharmacotherapy attacks the physical head - NRT provides controlled nicotine, varenicline blocks the receptor reward, bupropion addresses mood/craving. Counseling attacks the behavioral head - identifying triggers, developing coping strategies.
explanation.key_insight: Most smokers need MULTIPLE quit attempts before success - typically 4-7 attempts on average, with significant variation. Each attempt should be treated as progress, not failure. Clinicians should ask about tobacco at EVERY visit (not just first) because readiness changes. Brief advice at every visit has cumulative effect.
explanation.technical_details: Nicotine binds α4β2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the ventral tegmental area, triggering dopamine release in the nucleus accumbens (reward pathway). Varenicline is a partial agonist at α4β2 - provides 40-60% of dopamine response (reducing withdrawal) while blocking nicotine's full effect.

definitions_glossary.nicotine_dependence: Chronic relapsing condition characterized by compulsive tobacco use despite harm
definitions_glossary.varenicline: Partial nicotinic receptor agonist; most effective single cessation agent
definitions_glossary.NRT: Nicotine replacement therapy - patch, gum, lozenge, inhaler, nasal spray
definitions_glossary.bupropion: Norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor; reduces craving and withdrawal
definitions_glossary.5As_framework: Ask, Advise, Assess, Assist, Arrange - systematic approach to tobacco intervention
definitions_glossary.motivational_interviewing: Patient-centered counseling to enhance motivation to change
definitions_glossary.quit_date: Planned date to stop smoking; important for preparation and commitment
definitions_glossary.nicotine_withdrawal: Symptoms including irritability, anxiety, dysphoria, difficulty concentrating, increased appetite
definitions_glossary.Fagerstrom_test: Assessment of nicotine dependence severity based on smoking patterns
definitions_glossary.combination_NRT: Long-acting (patch) + short-acting (gum/lozenge) for baseline + breakthrough cravings
definitions_glossary.relapse: Return to smoking after period of abstinence; expected part of quit process
definitions_glossary.harm_reduction: Reducing tobacco-related harm when abstinence not achievable (e.g., e-cigarettes - controversial)

pathophysiology.mechanism: Nicotine addiction involves neurobiological changes in reward pathways, behavioral conditioning, and psychological dependence

nicotine_pharmacology.receptors: α4β2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (primary addiction mediator)
nicotine_pharmacology.reward: Dopamine release in nucleus accumbens → reinforcement
nicotine_pharmacology.tolerance: Receptor upregulation requires increasing nicotine for effect

withdrawal_syndrome.onset: Hours after last cigarette; peak 24-72 hours
withdrawal_syndrome.duration: Physical symptoms 2-4 weeks; cravings can persist months-years

assessment.tobacco_use: Type (cigarettes, cigars, pipes, smokeless), quantity, duration
assessment.readiness_to_quit: Stages of change: precontemplation, contemplation, preparation, action, maintenance

key_questions: Time to first cigarette after waking (≤5 min = high dependence)
Previous quit attempts and what helped/didn't help
Triggers for smoking (stress, meals, social, alcohol)

differential_diagnosis: ADHD (higher smoking rates, more difficult cessation)

varenicline.dosing: 0.5mg daily x 3 days, 0.5mg BID x 4 days, then 1mg BID for 12 weeks
varenicline.efficacy: Most effective single agent; OR 2.5-3x vs placebo

NRT.combination: Patch + gum/lozenge as effective as varenicline

bupropion.dosing: 150mg daily x 3 days, then 150mg BID for 12 weeks

combination.evidence: Varenicline + NRT may be more effective than either alone

5As.Ask: Systematically ask about tobacco use at every visit
5As.Advise: Clear, strong, personalized advice to quit
5As.Assist: Provide pharmacotherapy, counseling, set quit date
5As.Arrange: Follow-up contact within first week of quit date

counseling.efficacy: 4+ sessions most effective; any counseling doubles quit rate

special_populations.pregnancy: Behavioral counseling preferred; NRT if pharmacotherapy needed (FDA Category D)
special_populations.psychiatric: Can quit successfully; monitor mental health; varenicline safe
special_populations.hospitalized: Ideal opportunity; start intervention during stay

definition.@value: The process of discontinuing tobacco use through pharmacotherapy and behavioral interventions, addressing nicotine dependence as a chronic condition

scopeNote.@value: Covers pharmacotherapy options, 5 A's framework, and behavioral interventions for smoking cessation

learning_objectives: Apply the 5 A's framework to tobacco use intervention
Compare efficacy and dosing of varenicline, NRT, and bupropion
Explain why combination therapy is more effective than single agents
Assess nicotine dependence using Fagerstrom Test
Counsel patients that relapse is expected and part of the quit process
clinical_pearls: Varenicline most effective single agent; combination NRT equally effective
Brief advice (<3 min) at every visit increases quit rates 30%
Time to first cigarette ≤5 min after waking = high dependence
Multiple quit attempts typical (4-7 on average) - treat as chronic disease
common_misconceptions: E-cigarettes are proven cessation aids - evidence limited, not FDA-approved
Varenicline causes psychiatric problems - black box warning removed 2016
One quit attempt should work - typically 4-7 attempts before success
